text:
Poisonings in laboratory personnel and health care professionals.
 A case report of an unresponsive chemist presenting to the emergency department is presented; in retrospect, the patient was discovered to have intentionally ingested cyanide.
 A review of literature regarding ingestions in laboratory and health care personnel reveals five common points encountered in these personnel: barbiturates, carbon monoxide, cyanide, azides, and methemoglobin-inducing chemicals.
 Key diagnostic findings, in the absence of history of exposure, are discussed for these five agents.
